Description: Small mould-made scaraboid in Egyptian blue; back simply modelled with clypeus, prothorax and elytra indicated by single incised lines, with notches for humeral callosities; at side, legs not understood, represented by broad incised lines forming a triangle, but not cut away; underside incised with three hieroglyphs with, from right to left, Maat feather, owl and sun-disc; longitudinally pierced; in bright blue paste, of weathered, coarse texture.
Curator's comments: The drawing of the minute Egyptian blue scarab published by Petrie (Petrie 1886, pl. 37, no. 102; see scan of the drawing in this record) has some discrepancies, notably the Maat feather looking more like a nefer sign, but the silhouette of the owl is comparable between the drawing and BM 1886,0401.1658. The owl sign is often associated on Naukratite scarabs and scaraboids with solar symbols (see example of an owl between an obelisk and sun-disk in Gorton 1996, 103, no. 84) or other sacred signs (Maat feather, ankh sign: Gardner 1888, pl. 18, no. 42; Gorton 1996, 104). Though the hieroglyphic signs have often just some magical value, it seems plausible that this is a cryptographic reading for the name of Amun (various trigrams of Amun analysed in Drioton 1957). The scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Italy and Punic sites and in Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 109-111, type XXX A, subtype A19-31, see especially A26 for this piece). Variant of the same motif on scarabs and scaraboids from the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming): Petrie 1886, pl. 37, 99-104; Gardner 1888, pl. 18, 42. Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site', in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 102)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 110, Type XXX A26)
